primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God irrupts into the mundane and sinful lives of humans to reveal His presence, remove fear through His word, and sovereignly bestow redemption and a new vocation.

tekstueel_bewijs: God draws near to them both
He puts redemption into our blanket

object.identificatie: Redemption, 'New Things', and the removal of the barrier of sin/fear.
tekstueel_bewijs: new things, hidden things which you have not known

zender.identificatie: The Holy One of Israel / The Father
tekstueel_bewijs: the God who terrifies is also the one who loves us for all eternity

ontvanger.identificatie: The Hearer / Humanity (represented by Gideon, Peter, and the homeless woman)
tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus stoops down to us in our miserable condition
the Lord has laid on him the iniquity of us all

helper.identificatie: The Word of God / The Angel of the Lord / The Holy Spirit
tekstueel_bewijs: the fear is instantly removed by the enabling word 'Fear not'
anoint him with the Holy Spirit

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin, Death, and Human Resistance (Selfishness, Greed, Idolatry)
tekstueel_bewijs: God is opposed to our selfishness, greed, idolatry...
sin is to be conquered by the Son of God
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is described as a power that would lead to being 'lost' if allowed to play out; it requires a divine 'invasion' to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of following and serving (Gideon's task, Peter's fishing for men).
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (Gideon/Peter)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics/vocation) only begins after the primary program (grace/epiphany) has established the Subject's competence through the 'Fear not' word.

voorbeelden_god_subject: God will interrupt the normal progression
He puts redemption into our blanket
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We are trying to turn ourselves around

voorbeelden: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom (as a state of being, rather than a command)
We can understand and even admire the hope
before today you have never heard of them
has power to make our resistance go up in flames
sphere of power capable of calling into existence the things that do not exist

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on God's 'Pouvoir' (Power/Ability) to act where humans are 'deficient' or 'miserable'. Grace is presented as the endowment of competence to the incompetent.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S2 (Terror of the Holy) to ~S2 (Peace/Fear Not) via the action of S1 (Grace/Christ).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved by God taking the judgment (S2) upon Himself on the cross, allowing the sinner to move from hopelessness to grace.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The sermon emphasizes that 'Grace is terrifying' and God is truly 'opposed' to our sin.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. God is the primary actor; humans are recipients of an 'irruption' they did not initiate and do not deserve.

indicatoren_moralisme.indicator: Human effort mentioned but immediately qualified as insufficient.
indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: We are trying to turn ourselves around... [but] He does not ask what we are doing... he just gives the gift.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as the Subject of active verbs of salvation.
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus stoops down to us... he puts redemption into our blanket.
He does not ask for a receipt.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures are used as 'Receivers' of epiphany rather than 'Models' of behavior.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides the theocentric reading: Gideon is a 'nonentity' and Peter is 'sinful'; God is the hero who calls them.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and awe; moving from 'holy dread' to 'good tidings'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic grace; salvation is entirely God's work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the Old Testament (Gideon) to the New (Peter/Christ) is perfectly integrated through the theme of Epiphany.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: paying in his own body the price of sin

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin is an 'addiction' and 'rebelliousness' that leads to being 'lost'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon maintains a strict theocentric structure where God is the Subject and the human is the Receiver.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: The imbalance is homiletically appropriate for an Epiphany sermon.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: Opponent (Sin/Death) is already treated as a heavy, cosmic force.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (Program 1) clearly precedes and enables Ethics (Program 2).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-oriented preaching. It avoids the trap of 'exemplarism' and keeps the focus on the divine Subject.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis might focus on the 'funny' description of Gideon, Greimasian analysis shows Gideon's functional role as a 'Receiver' of divine competence.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the context of Midianites; semiotics explains the 'Axis of Power' where God overcomes the Midianites through Gideon.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'homeless woman' and 'Peter' occupy the same actantial slot (Receiver), proving the sermon's structural consistency across metaphors.

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully utilizes the 'Heavy Opponent' to make the 'Grace' actant truly powerful rather than sentimental.
